Guys. I need help.

I saw an advertisement of Afremov's paintings. I really like his style mostly because of vibrant colors and I thought that having such a painting on my wall would be cool. One of them caught my attention, see the pic.

Now I'm thinking that maybe I could copy this painting myself. The only problem is, the last time I held a brush in my hand was in kindergarden, and even back then I was known for having the least art skill, even for a child.

But copying a painting shouldn't be that difficult, right? The style isn't realistic, so even if I make mistakes, they won't stand out.

The rough plan would be:

1. In a computer program trace shapes so that I can make a sketch of what I want
2. Print the sketch
3. Trace the sketch on a canvas with a pencil
4. Color the sketch with oil paint and brush

Going up to step 3 doesn't seem like a big challenge, even for a such talentless person as me. But step 4 will be difficult and I have absolutely no clue how to even approach this. Can you help me?

Why You Should Copy Anime:
https://i.imgur.com/zNDsyF0.jpg
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kbKqIJcIUCw
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dgjx6y6B_G8

**Strive for quantity AND quality.**

Anime Studying:
>Copy anime references exactly and draw them from memory. Use illustrations, screenshots, anime figures, 3D models, etc.
>Don’t copy recklessly. Use construction, color theory, and other fundamental concepts to rehearse a drawing process that you can later easily manipulate for original artwork.
>Post all of your anime studies. Post even when you’re told not to. Create an art community that actually draws and improves together instead of just talking about it.
>Number your attempts and link to your previous posts.
>Critiquers should lead by example by posting their studies.

General Anime Style Discussion:
>Questions about achieving certain styles/techniques/compositions etc.
>Drawing methods, study habits, resources, tutorials, tools, software, etc
>Be specific and try to post a sample of your study attempts before asking for help.

**Draw copies from good anime styled references to mindfully up our mileage, internalize appealing aesthetics, and learn from each other’s processes and knowledge.**

threads.com:
This thread is dedicated to master studies, where you copy artwork you admire as a form of study. They are the quickest way to improve and learn about any fundamental you are having problems with. If you need to work on your hands, copy hands from other artists, and if you're having trouble with rendering, make careful studies of paintings with lighting you admire. Studies can be quick or long. You can even copy anatomy books like Bridgman, Morpho, and Hogarth. The type of studies you want to do depend on your personal goals and the types of problems you are grappling with.

Artists of all levels are welcome. Critiques and redlines are encouraged.

>>6402074
it can be very cheap if you can source it locally
you can alter its hardness by moisture content for a wide range of finishes and effects
can further alter its qualities by adding fibers or some sand.
if it gets dirt you can thin with water and strain.
you can moisten it with sponge or spray water. most store it in plastic bags to keep moist. another way is to cover it in moist cloth.

cons are that it can develop bacteria compared to oil based clays, can have mica, you might need to make a board of plaster to control moisture (making workable clay out of quite wet clay), and need to attend to it more than other clays. that last one can be an advantage because it may make you want to work on it more instead of just letting it sit covered.

last_replies.com:
Take a blank piece of paper, and with a pencil, scribble on it for 3 seconds. Then with a pen,try turning part of the scribble into something that the random shapes suggest to you.

And as test for yourself, attempt a larger work,and do the required homework. That being approaching the project piecemeal,thinking of the scene and working out how the characters are interacting with each other. Compose on very cheap paper very quickly, rough sketches to place people and props,and the angles of view involved. Then you design the elements of the picture. In sketchbooks, taking your time to be experimental. Then,once you are happy with your final pictures, you can refer to them as you lay out the penultimate work. In this one,Ihad to think about what these Magmamen were like,and the final result is only serviceable, but the 5 previous attempts in my research sketchbook were far worse. Remember that you have no time restraints, so taking the time to try new things is now. Even Davinci liked to draw bits of things.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6401748
How can you be sincere but not put in effort? Sincerity means being genuine, lacking pretense. What does that mean in art? Because art is at its core an expression of one's consciousness in a deliberate, non-verbal visual format, we can assume the reason someone sincerely draws two characters interacting is because they feel strongly about those characters. And when humans feel strongly about some object or being, they place value on what they perceive to be the defining traits therein. So, regardless of the execution, an artist with sincere interest in their subject would be mindful to deliberately capture what they see as significant about the subject. What's significant about the subjects in the OP? Besides the horns or whatever those are, it's effectively just some squiggles representing an action between two humanoid beings. Not much more soulful than a wet floor sign with horns on one of the figures.

last_replies.com:
>>6401902
You can't get output without input. Draw interesting poses from reference and browse art you like before you try to come up with stuff if you keep drawing a blank and can't imagine much.
Another thing to keep in mind is that it's better to draw actions than poses, like how it's better to draw environments rather than backgrounds. It might sound like trivial semantics but changing the way you think about things from isolated to parts of a whole makes it much easier to come up with ideas. You're not drawing a pose, you're drawing an [adjective] picture of [character] doing something.

No art supplies thread so I made one.
Is artist grade Gouache worth it? I watched some Lightfastness test of famous artist grade gouaches and think they aren't that much different than my current cheap Chinese gouache. Are there any other quality to considered?
I also want to start painting with acrylic. Do it need any special medium like oil paint or just apply directly on canvas?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6372892
Yes, you need 100% cotton paper if youre going to to do any work of quality and that which you intend to either preserve or sell. Practice is alright i guess for 50% cotton but I dont even use it anymore. I buy whole sheets of arches and cut it down to size for sketchbooks and such. Buying the whole sheets is ultimately cheaper than the arches blocks and I think its easier than trying to carefully pry the page off the block.

It is important to buyers, yes. You shouldn't sell someone something that isn't going to hold up over time. This also includes you using artist grade watercolors that have good light fastness instead of cheap student grade watercolors.

You should really kina know these things before you start selling product. You need to do your homework.

last_replies.com:
>>6399942
>using tweens for bouncing ball
Holy shit would anyone actually do that??
Tweens are mostly useful for having things slide in and out of frame, kind of like panning a camera around in a video game.
All of the actual keyframes and inbetweens can be animated in their own space and then tweened to move through a scene to simulate movement through space.
So say you need a character to walk from A to B but they’re basically in a walking loop of 8 keyframes. You can animate them walking in a loop and then tween them from A to B instead of manually placing each keyframe in space.
It really doesn’t work for just everything. I animate in CSP so idk what tweening is like in other programs.
>>6399966
I think you guys just misunderstand the animation tool a bit, or have been soured by really shitty flash/puppet animation.
>>6399989
>many digital art tools are just a computer implementation of existing traditional tools
This. For the walk cycle example I gave, it’d be equivalent to moving the character walk loop as cels through a painted environment if we were using pre-digital animation techniques, and just moving the whole loop through the shot very slow. Still the same number of frames looping.
Like the panning shots in Akira’s opening doesn’t have every single asset redrawn, they were very strategic about what could be kept static and what needed to move, for some shots there’s no animation at all and they’re just sliding cels around.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6397485
>If you choose to not teach yourself or are incapable of it where do you go to learn how to draw? Who in this field is a credible teacher? What about schools?
If you can't self-teach you lack discipline. Go to an atelier, they'll drill good habits to you. What you need most is someone to hold you accountable so you'll actually do the exercises.

>>6398124
Apprentices back in the day primarily copied older works. Michelangelo was apprenticed late (at 13) to Domenico Ghirlandaio, and left one year later having nothing more to learn. Largest amount of his practice was self-propelled, though as he was under the wing of Lorenzo de´ Medici, he had access to the Medici art collection to study from - primarily ancient roman statues.
These days you have access to way more art, and the method to learn from it remains the same: Copy it until you can produce your own. Download art, get a good quality print made, and copy it. Rinse and repeat. Go to a museum to sketch, rinse and repeat. That really is almost all there is to it. The rest is knowing your materials, on which there's tons of resources of incredible quality available now.

threads.sub: What should I choose as the next course as a beginner?
threads.com:
Hi anons, hoping i can get some serious replies here because for some reason I trust you fucking autists.

I completed Drawing on the Right Side of the Brain and then realized I wasn't very confident so i did Brent Eviston's The Art and Science of Drawing. I've completed that now and feeling a bit better about my basic skills but obviously there's a lot more to learn. I have a high stress job and i don't prioritize art as much as I'd like to (it's just a hobby), hopefully next year I will have more time to sit down and practice more, but i'm not looking to make it as an artist, i just wanna be able to draw stuff.

I kind of want to do a figure drawing course next because ultimately a lot of what i want to draw is characters but I'm also still kind of worried I don't have great fundamentals when it comes to construction. I noticed that I still have trouble making shapes on the page that are the same proportion as what i'm seeing in real life. Like, i will be drawing a bowl and i make the oval for the rim in perspective, but because the oval doesn't have the same openness as what i'm seeing in real life it just looks like a bowl with a different shape.

Was hoping y'all could guide me on how to choose my next steps. Ultimately i want to do character and some environment stuff. My current favorite artists (in not particular order, all instagram handles) are:
- chenlongchung
- lotusbubble
- cudlittle
- samdoesarts
- tiger_june
- xa_gueuzav
- rossdraws
- philipsue.art (has made me wanna learn environments)

So the art i'm trying to achieve is both manga/anime style as well as more digitally painterly stuff.

Right now i'm considering doing Draw a Box simultaneously with some other course (figure maybe?). I was hoping DAB would help me get better at making shapes more consistently, i hear *constantly* that DAB is a trap but it feels like grinding the shapes might help me? idk what to think.

Hopefully y'all could offer some insight here into what good next steps are.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>6400372
The question of finding a 'unique vision' is, in my opinion, not helpful. It's an artifact of western fine arts abandoning any notion of a canon or craft to pursue sheer novelty (ending, finally, in banana-taped-to-wall type art, that is all "vision", with no skill or craft).

Not that the unique vision of an artist does not exist, but it's something cultivated over years of work and problem solving, rather than pursued as an end unto itself. Think of a football player who gets so wrapped up in striking a dramatic pose for the cameras that he is distracted and preoccupied at the moment of throwing the ball.

Not sure what can be done about it; self conscious efforts to revive old craft technique are usually only partial successes.

threads.com:
Hey, guys. Can anyone here tell me how to properly choose colors when shading. My current method of shading is that I usually paint black on Overlay layers with different opacity, constantly switching until I find one that I think is right but usually that method is very time consuming due to how I need to constantly switch around multiple layers. Plus, my art would sometimes look plastic like from the colors.
Is there a guide I could use so that I can find the perfect color to shade and make it look less waxy.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6398576
because there are technically no "right" or "wrong" colors to use, since it all depends on the context of the image, try looking up some images that have color schemes that appeal to you and eyedrop tool those.
in general, a lot of the "plastic" feeling comes from the fact that your colors are all very saturated and do not influence each other or are influenced by some sort of environment. a more realistic look would be achieved by muting colors and adapting them to each other.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6398584
So what you're saying is to find shading that I like. Eyedrop what color they use to shade a certain color and use it to as a guide?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: I usually go inch warmer and more saturated and maybe bit more darker than the base color. For skin I make another round of shading with even more red to give that vibrant touch

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6400309
not quite. instead of finding "shading you like", find a "picture you like" and then analyze how the shading and light in that picture relate to the colors of the things in the picture.
are the shadows more saturated? shifted more red/blue/whatever? what is the light situation around them? is it night? something like that.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6398576
First of all I hope you are doing well anon
Second, Sorry about the armor, I know you were going for a more "cell shaded" look but you can still simplify this example

So lets start with this, NEVER SHADE WITH BLACK! if you are going the Overlay method go with dark blue, red, purple or green
If you wanna shade something directly remember that Regular whites are boring, always tint whites slightly with yellow or cyan, or any color for that matter
When you pick a darker color for the shadow, don't just drag the slider to black and call it a day, hue shift towards a cooler color
also this is already told by the other anons but here it is again, look up your favorite artists, color pick:
-the base color
-The shadow color
compare the two and see how you did he pick the shadow color, did he lower the satuaration of the color? maybe only hue shifted it towards blue and made it slightly darker?
Also look up how different materials react to light, learn proper shadow placement, sometimes shadows arent just darker versions of the regular color, maybe ambient light from the background is bouncing on it
Pinterest has a shit ton of refs and tutorials about shading, and the website's algorithm will help you find artists that have elements of your targeted artstyle
Check out:
- Speedo
- Alex Ahad
- Dreamin'
- KAINONAUT

They have colorful and interesting formulas, if you wanna do it your way, study real light and exaggerate it

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: How do I get this good at light and shading?
threads.com: How does one learn to color and shade like this?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Y'alls posting absolutely useless advice. You don't need high level rendering skills for OP's pic.

There's a standard formula for this type of image:
1. Draw base color. We'll paint light to dark, so do pale light pink for skin, mid orange for hair.
2. Take a flat brush and pick a darker shade of pink. Paint the shadows cel-style. Same for hair using a darker shade of orange.
3. Take the blur tool, run it thru the edges of the shadow.
4. Add finishing touches like highlights.etc.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6393877
Lasso and soft brush mainly. Put down your flats (make them your mid tone), then create a clipping mask layer ontop. Then paint in the ambient shadows with a soft brushsoft, (the general form shadows not the drop shadows). Then on the same layer with the same color lay down your drop shadows using the lasso. Might want to duplicate the ambient layer first for back up incase you screw up. To clean it up I would make another clipping layer ontop of the last one and paint over top sample from underneath. This is a really simple base to start from. The real trick to making great shadows is understanding the your darker skin tones and your shadows are NOT THE SAME. They overlap, so what you want to do is make the base I just explained your darker skin tones then ontop of all you did brush your true shadow color in selectively. The easiest way to find your shadow is to sample from your background. The warm skin cool shadow, cool skin warm shadow thing is more about creating good contrast between the subject and the background then actually making proper shadows. So, before you start dropping in shadows figure out your background. Shadows are also sponges for color so if you want to dial them up even more you can try putting different colors from around the painting in different areas, just don't get carried away or they won't gel right. After that it's high lights, bounce lights, and subsurface scattering. Oh, and I said Lasso and softbruch mainly but every painting is comes down to both soft and hard brush. It's doesn't matter which one you start with, it just matters that you know when to soften and when to harden. The Lasso is just best for making perfect gradients that even the best soft brush technique can't produce as quickly. Ok, that's it from me, cheers.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: beginner here. do you actually have to study anatomy at an autistic level to get good? I flipped through this book and this shit feels like med school. do people actually study all these muscles and bones?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6396939

It depends on your ambition.

It has been a centuries long tradition among artists to study skeletons and cadavers. We don't really have to do that per se today, though I would recommend checking out a few dissection videos on youtube if you can stomach them - a bit more reality than some dude's pencils.

Anatomy shouldn't be the first thing you jump on, like the other guy said. When you start getting into figure drawing, make sure you learn a good system of whole-body proportions first.

You can get by quite a bit with using references as often as you can but many successful artists still study every bone and muscle from books and models - there's a huge power to it (and fun). It's also easier than ever, there are so many available resources today, books and articles, skull casts on Amazon, 3D models on sketchfab, you name it.

>do I gotta learn all that shit

The shapes of the skeleton and the muscles look extremely daunting at first, but there's a certain rhythm to everything that makes it all simpler once you learn it. All muscles work in conjunction and follow just a few key patterns. Plus, the body is symmetrical so you only need to know half of it.

You should also know where to place your priorities. The skull is really helpful to understand in detail - the ribcage and pelvis are hidden under layers and can be more simplified. The knee is useful to understand because it's very shallow, but the leg bones are hidden under layers and layers of fat and muscle. The same with muscles, arm muscles tend to be more defined than the stomach or the legs.

last_replies.com:
A MEANS TO AN END
>Anatomy in the hands of the artist is merely an other instrument for making the figure articulate and clear. It is never to be thought of as an end in itself but only as a means to an end. It is quite possible for a student to acquire sufficient knowledge of anatomy through his knowledge of the figure without having made any special study of the subject or ever even having heard the word.
>The archaic Greeks knew little of anatomy and their figures are anatomically inaccurate, but they constitute great works of art. The knowledge of anatomy can become an interesting thing for itself without regard to art, but purely anatomical drawings of the figure are like the drawings a botanist without art training might make of flowers. They are good diagrams but are unimportant as far as art is concerned. The student who self-consciously displays his knowledge of anatomy on every occasion is apt to be as boring and as impotent as the kind of person who feels it necessary to parade his information on any other subject.
>Anatomy is the one study on which I do not advise students to concentrate in the beginning. Rather, approach it lightly and casually in the same way that you would make drawings during a telephone conversation. Think less of the anatomy than of the figure as you know it, fitting the anatomy into your knowledge of the figure even though your knowledge is not yet exactly correct. I have seen so often a lot of waste energy, disillusionment, and disappointment among students because nothing `works' in the beginning.
>It takes many drawings, many efforts, to relate the information in anatomy charts to what you know of the figure through your other experience with it. Therefore, it is better not to take the study too seriously at first or to devote too much time to it. But it should be continued and, if it is, the anatomy will become comprehensible and you will find yourself more interested, more serious about it, and more able to concentrate.
